content.full_text:
Abraham Lincoln to George Spears, 1 At your request, I send you a receipt for the postage on yourpaper— I am some what surprised at your request— I will however comply with it— The law

requires News

paper postage to be paid in advance and now that I have waited a full year you choose

to wound my

feelings by insinuating that unless you get a receipt I will probably make you pay

it again— Received of George Spears in full for postage on theSangamo Journalup to the first of

July 1834

feelings by insinuating that unless you get a receipt I will probably make you pay
it again— Received of George Spears in full for postage on theSangamo Journalup to the first of

footnotes.text: 2This could beGeorge Spears Sr.or hissonof the same name.

3PresidentAndrew Jacksonappointed Lincoln  postmaster ofNew Salemon May 7, 1833. He held the position until the post office was closed on May 30,
                  1836.

structured_content.text: Abraham Lincoln to George Spears, [1 July 1834]1

At your request, I send you a receipt for the postage on yourpaper— I am some what surprised at your request— I will however comply with it— The law
               requires News
               paper postage to be paid in advance and now that I have waited a full year you choose
               to wound my
               feelings by insinuating that unless you get a receipt I will probably make you pay
               it again—

Received of George Spears in full for postage on theSangamo Journalup to the first of
               July 1834
